elements.content: A novel entangled architecture formed on solvothermal reaction of a imidazolium based bent ligand with Cd(NO3)2, showing 1D channels decorated with imidazolium groups, is reported. The polymer, {[Cd2(L)3(DMF)(NO3)](DMF)3(H2O)8} n (1) (where H2L = 1,3-bis(4-carboxyphenyl)imidazolium, DMF = dimethylformamide), shows an interesting 6,3-connected polycatenated structure with channels along the crystallographic b-axis occupied with large number of DMF and water molecules. On removal of these solvent molecules the compound maintains its overall structure. Proton conductivity investigation affords a proton conductivity of 1.3 × 10–5 Scm–1 at 25 °C and 98% RH when water molecules are introduced into the empty channels.
elements.clean_text: A novel entangled architecture formed on solvothermal reaction of a imidazolium based bent ligand with Cd(NO3)2, showing 1D channels decorated with imidazolium groups, is reported. The polymer, {[Cd2(L)3(DMF)(NO3)](DMF)3(H2O)8} n  (1) (where H2L = 1,3-bis(4-carboxyphenyl)imidazolium, DMF = dimethylformamide), shows an interesting 6,3-connected polycatenated structure with channels along the crystallographic b-axis occupied with large number of DMF and water molecules. On removal of these solvent molecules the compound maintains its overall structure. Proton conductivity investigation affords a proton conductivity of 1.3 × 10-5 Scm-1 at 25 °C and 98% RH when water molecules are introduced into the empty channels.

elements.content:
A novel coordination polymer of Cd(II) with an imidazolium ligand has been synthesized solvothermally. The compound exhibits polycatenation and shows proton conduction property.

Introduction

Coordination polymers, generated through choice of ligands and utilizing the coordination tendencies of the metal ions are important for potential applications. Porous coordination polymers (PCPs) are quite useful in various applications, such as gas storage, separation, catalysis, guest–responsive porosity, stepwise gas adsorption, and so on. In many cases, coordination polymers show entanglement of individual motifs. As new organic linkers are used with different metal ions, many fascinating modes of entangled structures are formed. Among these, compounds showing entanglement in the form of polycatenation constitute an important class of novel supramolecular entities endowed with possible practical utilities. The bent linker (H2L+) used here is functionalized with an imidazolium moiety in the middle and aromatic carboxylate groups at the terminals (Scheme ). We report a 3D coordination polymer, {[Cd2(L)3(DMF)(NO3)](DMF)3(H2O)8} n (1), that consists 3-fold interpenetrated network and in hierarchical fashion forms a 3D structure via parallel polycatenation. In this structure, imidazolium groups are aligned inside the channels although not closely packed like our previous compound. However, since the framework also contains lattice solvent molecules, it was subjected to proton conductivity. Because, this gives us a starting point to synthesize MOFs for possible proton conductivity. Recently, PCPs are investigated as proton conducting separator materials for potential use in fuel cells. In this regard, PCPs having channels incorporating guest molecules such as imidazole, triazaole in anhydrous medium, or water chains, water clusters, metal-coordinated water molecules in humid conditions, can potentially act as proton carriers. We report proton conductivity of 1 at different relative humidity.
elements.clean_text:
A novel coordination polymer of Cd(II) with an imidazolium ligand has been synthesized solvothermally. The compound exhibits polycatenation and shows proton conduction property.

Introduction

Coordination polymers, generated through choice of ligands and utilizing the coordination tendencies of the metal ions are important for potential applications. Porous coordination polymers (PCPs) are quite useful in various applications, such as gas storage, separation, catalysis, guest-responsive porosity, stepwise gas adsorption, and so on. In many cases, coordination polymers show entanglement of individual motifs. As new organic linkers are used with different metal ions, many fascinating modes of entangled structures are formed. Among these, compounds showing entanglement in the form of polycatenation constitute an important class of novel supramolecular entities endowed with possible practical utilities. The bent linker (H2L+) used here is functionalized with an imidazolium moiety in the middle and aromatic carboxylate groups at the terminals (Scheme ). We report a 3D coordination polymer, {[Cd2(L)3(DMF)(NO3)](DMF)3(H2O)8} n  (1), that consists 3-fold interpenetrated network and in hierarchical fashion forms a 3D structure via parallel polycatenation. In this structure, imidazolium groups are aligned inside the channels although not closely packed like our previous compound. However, since the framework also contains lattice solvent molecules, it was subjected to proton conductivity. Because, this gives us a starting point to synthesize MOFs for possible proton conductivity. Recently, PCPs are investigated as proton conducting separator materials for potential use in fuel cells. In this regard, PCPs having channels incorporating guest molecules such as imidazole, triazaole in anhydrous medium, or water chains, water clusters, metal-coordinated water molecules in humid conditions, can potentially act as proton carriers. We report proton conductivity of 1 at different relative humidity.

elements.content: Reagent grade 4-aminobenzoic acid, glyoxal (30% aqueous solution) and paraformaldehyde acquired from Aldrich were used as received. The metal salt, Cd(NO3)2·6H2O and all solvents were from Fluka Chemicals. All solvents were purified prior to use following standard procedures.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Procedure

Materials

Reagent grade 4-aminobenzoic acid, glyoxal (30% aqueous solution) and paraformaldehyde acquired from Aldrich were used as received. The metal salt, Cd(NO3)2⋅6H2O and all solvents were from Fluka Chemicals. All solvents were purified prior to use following standard procedures.

elements.content: Spectroscopic data were collected as follows: IR spectra (KBr disk, 400–4000 cm–1) were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer Model 1320 spectrometer. Temperature dependent X-ray powder patterns (nickel-filtered Cu Kα radiation, 3 degree/min scan rate, 293 K) were acquired using a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (5 degree/min heating rate under a nitrogen atmosphere) was performed with a Mettler Toledo Star System. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a JEOL JNM-LA500 FT instrument (500 MHz) in DMSO-d6 with TMS as the internal standard. Melting points were recorded on an electrical melting point apparatus by PERFIT India and are uncorrected. Elemental analyses were executed with the Central Drug Research Institute, Lucknow, India.
elements.clean_text:
Measurements

Spectroscopic data were collected as follows: IR spectra (KBr disk, 400-4000 cm-1) were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer Model 1320 spectrometer. Temperature dependent X-ray powder patterns (nickel-filtered Cu Kα radiation, 3 degree/min scan rate, 293 K) were acquired using a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (5 degree/min heating rate under a nitrogen atmosphere) was performed with a Mettler Toledo Star System. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a JEOL JNM-LA500 FT instrument (500 MHz) in DMSO-d6 with TMS as the internal standard. Melting points were recorded on an electrical melting point apparatus by PERFIT India and are uncorrected. Elemental analyses were executed with the Central Drug Research Institute, Lucknow, India.

elements.content:
The ligand 1, 3-bis-(4-carboxyphenyl)imidazolium chloride (H2L+Cl–) was synthesized in several steps as reported earlier.

Synthesis of [Cd<sub>2</sub>(L)<sub>3</sub>(DMF)(NO<sub>3</sub>)]·(DMF)<sub>3</sub>·(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>8</sub>(<bold>1</bold>)

This compound was synthesized by mixing H2L+Cl– (1 mmol) and Cd(NO3)2·6H2O (4 mmol) in DMF (3 mL) in a Teflon-lined autoclave. It was heated under autogenous pressure to 85 °C for 48 h. Cooling to room temperature at the rate of 10 °C h–1 afforded the desired product as colorless needle-shaped crystals in ca. 66% yield. It was collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with DMF followed by ethanol and dried in air. Anal. Calcd for C63H77N11O27Cd2: C, 45.99; H, 4.72; N, 9.37%. Found: C, 46.13; H, 4.93; N, 9.24%.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

The ligand 1, 3-bis-(4-carboxyphenyl)imidazolium chloride (H2L+Cl-) was synthesized in several steps as reported earlier. 

Synthesis of [Cd2(L)3(DMF)(NO3)]⋅(DMF)3⋅(H2O)8(1)

This compound was synthesized by mixing H2L+Cl- (1 mmol) and Cd(NO3)2⋅6H2O (4 mmol) in DMF (3 mL) in a Teflon-lined autoclave. It was heated under autogenous pressure to 85 °C for 48 h. Cooling to room temperature at the rate of 10 °C h-1 afforded the desired product as colorless needle-shaped crystals in ca. 66% yield. It was collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with DMF followed by ethanol and dried in air. Anal. Calcd for C63H77N11O27Cd2: C, 45.99; H, 4.72; N, 9.37%. Found: C, 46.13; H, 4.93; N, 9.24%.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray data of 1 were collected at 100 K on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71069 Å). The linear absorption coefficients, scattering factors for the atoms, and the anomalous dispersion corrections were taken from International Tables for X-ray Crystallography. The data integration and reduction were processed with SAINT software. An empirical absorption correction was applied to the collected reflections with SADABS using XPREP. The structure was solved by the direct method using SHELXTL and was refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL-97 program package. The lattice parameters and structural data are collected in Table S1.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Structural Studies

Single-crystal X-ray data of 1 were collected at 100 K on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71069 Å). The linear absorption coefficients, scattering factors for the atoms, and the anomalous dispersion corrections were taken from International Tables for X-ray Crystallography. The data integration and reduction were processed with SAINT software. An empirical absorption correction was applied to the collected reflections with SADABS using XPREP. The structure was solved by the direct method using SHELXTL and was refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL-97 program package. The lattice parameters and structural data are collected in  Table S1.

elements.content: Water adsorption and desorption isotherms were collected at 25 °C with an automatic vapor adsorption apparatus, BELSORP-max (BEL Japan). Measurements were executed after elimination of guests by evacuation of the sample at 80 °C for over 4 h.
elements.clean_text:
Water Uptake Measurement

Water adsorption and desorption isotherms were collected at 25 °C with an automatic vapor adsorption apparatus, BELSORP-max (BEL Japan). Measurements were executed after elimination of guests by evacuation of the sample at 80 °C for over 4 h.

elements.content:
Impedance measurements were carried out using a pellet of 2.5 mm thickness as described earlier.

Results and Discussion

Compound 1 once isolated, is found to be air-stable and insoluble in common organic solvents and water. Thermal analysis of 1 shows ( Figure S1) loss of weight of ∼26.5% in the range, 40–200 °C corresponding to the removal of free as well as coordinated solvent molecules. Decomposition of the compound is achieved beyond 350 °C. A broad peak in the IR spectrum ( Figure S2) at 3224 cm–1 appears due to water molecules and strong peaks are observed at 1607 and 2921 cm–1 attributable to the CO and C–H stretching of coordinated DMF molecules respectively. The asymmetric stretching vibration of the chelating nitrate is observed at 1258 cm–1. Single crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c. The asymmetric unit contains two crystallographically independent Cd(II) ions; octa-coordinated Cd1 and hexacoordinated Cd2 (Figure ).
elements.clean_text:
AC Impedance Measurement

Impedance measurements were carried out using a pellet of 2.5 mm thickness as described earlier. 

Results and Discussion

Compound 1 once isolated, is found to be air-stable and insoluble in common organic solvents and water. Thermal analysis of 1 shows ( Figure S1) loss of weight of ~26.5% in the range, 40-200 °C corresponding to the removal of free as well as coordinated solvent molecules. Decomposition of the compound is achieved beyond 350 °C. A broad peak in the IR spectrum ( Figure S2) at 3224 cm-1 appears due to water molecules and strong peaks are observed at 1607 and 2921 cm-1 attributable to the CO and C-H stretching of coordinated DMF molecules respectively. The asymmetric stretching vibration of the chelating nitrate is observed at 1258 cm-1. Single crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c. The asymmetric unit contains two crystallographically independent Cd(II) ions; octa-coordinated Cd1 and hexacoordinated Cd2 (Figure ).

elements.content: Coordination environment of (a) Cd1 and (b) Cd2. Brown, blue, white, and red spheres represent Cd, N, C, and O, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 1  Coordination environment of (a) Cd1 and (b) Cd2. Brown, blue, white, and red spheres represent Cd, N, C, and O, respectively.

elements.content: Cd1 is coordinated by three carboxylate groups from three different ligands and one nitrate anion in chelated fashion. Cd2 is coordinated by two carboxylate groups from two different ligands in chelated mode, one carboxylate O atom of the third ligand in monodentate fashion, and one O atom of a DMF molecule. The noncoordinated O atom of the monodentate carboxylate is H-bonded to a nearby methylene H of the imidazolium moiety (H···O, 2.05 Å) ( Figure S3). We could locate six water and two DMF molecules in the asymmetric unit. Besides, some more disordered solvent molecules present in the lattice which could not be modeled as discrete atomic sites. We employed PLATON/SQUEEZE to calculate the diffraction contribution of solvent molecules and, thereby generated a solvent-free data set of diffraction intensities. Structure was then refined again using the data generated. The SQUEEZE result is in good agreement with the presence of three DMF and eight water molecules in the lattice (count of 201 electrons vs theoretical 200). This assignment is well-supported by TGA, elemental analyses and the IR spectrum of the compound (see for details). Qualitative test for chloride ion was negative. Interestingly the metal–ligand ensemble forms hexagonal grid like network containing large cavities of approximately 39.1 Å × 27.4 Å based on the distances of the opposite atoms (Figure a).
elements.clean_text: Cd1 is coordinated by three carboxylate groups from three different ligands and one nitrate anion in chelated fashion. Cd2 is coordinated by two carboxylate groups from two different ligands in chelated mode, one carboxylate O atom of the third ligand in monodentate fashion, and one O atom of a DMF molecule. The noncoordinated O atom of the monodentate carboxylate is H-bonded to a nearby methylene H of the imidazolium moiety (H⋅⋅⋅O, 2.05 Å) ( Figure S3). We could locate six water and two DMF molecules in the asymmetric unit. Besides, some more disordered solvent molecules present in the lattice which could not be modeled as discrete atomic sites. We employed PLATON/SQUEEZE to calculate the diffraction contribution of solvent molecules and, thereby generated a solvent-free data set of diffraction intensities. Structure was then refined again using the data generated. The SQUEEZE result is in good agreement with the presence of three DMF and eight water molecules in the lattice (count of 201 electrons vs theoretical 200). This assignment is well-supported by TGA, elemental analyses and the IR spectrum of the compound (see  for details). Qualitative test for chloride ion was negative. Interestingly the metal-ligand ensemble forms hexagonal grid like network containing large cavities of approximately 39.1 Å × 27.4 Å based on the distances of the opposite atoms (Figure a).

elements.content: (a) Perspective view of hexagonal-grid-like network of 1. (b) Space fill presentation of Wave like 2D sheets along the c-axis of 1.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Perspective view of hexagonal-grid-like network of 1. (b) Space fill presentation of Wave like 2D sheets along the c-axis of 1.

elements.content: Because of the coordination mode of the metal ion, the angular nature of the ligand and partial rotation of the imidazolium moiety with respect to the benzene moiety, the grids are puckered. These hexagonal grid forms a wave like 2D sheet (Figure b). Three such sheets are interpenetrated with each other and forms a 3-fold interpenetrated network. Three such 3-fold interpenetrated networks undergo parallel polycatenation (Figure a and b) to form an entangled 3D structure.
elements.clean_text: Because of the coordination mode of the metal ion, the angular nature of the ligand and partial rotation of the imidazolium moiety with respect to the benzene moiety, the grids are puckered. These hexagonal grid forms a wave like 2D sheet (Figure b). Three such sheets are interpenetrated with each other and forms a 3-fold interpenetrated network. Three such 3-fold interpenetrated networks undergo parallel polycatenation (Figure a and b) to form an entangled 3D structure.

elements.content: (a) Schematic representation of the polycatenated framework viewed down the a-axis. (b) View down the b-axis.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Schematic representation of the polycatenated framework viewed down the a-axis. (b) View down the b-axis.

elements.content: The overall 3D structure of 1 also features channels along the b-axis (Figure b and c). The channels are not empty but contain water and dimethylformamide molecules as guests. Dimension of each channel is 11.09 × 10.63 Å2 based on the distances of the opposite atoms (Figure b). Some of the methylene groups of the imidazolium moieties are directed toward the center of the channel (Figure c). The variable temperature powder X-ray diffraction studies confirms the stability of the framework ( Figure S4).

Dimension of each channel is 11.09 × 10.63 Å2 based on the distances of the opposite atoms (Figure b). Some of the methylene groups of the imidazolium moieties are directed toward the center of the channel (Figure c). The variable temperature powder X-ray diffraction studies confirms the stability of the framework ( Figure S4).

elements.content: (a) View of 1D channels of the polycatenated framework down the b-axis and (b) its space-filling model. (c) Alignment of imidazolium groups along the 1D channels.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) View of 1D channels of the polycatenated framework down the b-axis and (b) its space-filling model. (c) Alignment of imidazolium groups along the 1D channels.

elements.content: Proton conductivity was evaluated by AC impedance spectroscopy using a compacted pellet of the powdered sample with two gold electrodes attached to the surface. Detailed experimental procedures are available elsewhere. Proton conductivity of 1 gradually increases with increase of humidity and it reaches the value of 1.3 × 10–5 S cm–1 at 25 °C under 98% relative humidity (RH) (Figure ). The conductivity increases by about 4 orders of magnitude, from 9.8 × 10–10 at 40% RH to 1.3 × 10–5 S cm–1 at 98% RH.
elements.clean_text: Proton conductivity was evaluated by AC impedance spectroscopy using a compacted pellet of the powdered sample with two gold electrodes attached to the surface. Detailed experimental procedures are available elsewhere. Proton conductivity of 1 gradually increases with increase of humidity and it reaches the value of 1.3 × 10-5 S cm-1 at 25 °C under 98% relative humidity (RH) (Figure ). The conductivity increases by about 4 orders of magnitude, from 9.8 × 10-10 at 40% RH to 1.3 × 10-5 S cm-1 at 98% RH.

elements.content: Only slight hysteresis is observed between adsorption and desorption of water (Figure ). As shown in Figure , the proton conductivity depends on the water amount inside the pore of the MOF. Proton conductivity of 1 up to the penta-hydrate state is low. Thereafter, addition of water molecules enhances its conductivity significantly suggesting that the water molecules in the channel play important role in the proton conduction probably due to the formation of hydrogen bond networks. The results suggest that small amount of protons are coordinated by water and the emerged oxonium ion acts as proton carrier. According to the literature, possibly Grötthuss type of conduction takes place here with the participation of water molecules and the aligned imidazolium groups. However, this compound does not give high proton conductivity compared to the Zn(II) coordination polymer. This is most likely due to inefficient Grötthuss type of conduction as the nitrate anion is coordinated to the metal center. This assumes importance as in the previous case, the nitrate anion was free. As we are synthesizing other PCPs for high proton conductivity, this study gives us an important starting point.
elements.clean_text: Only slight hysteresis is observed between adsorption and desorption of water (Figure ). As shown in Figure , the proton conductivity depends on the water amount inside the pore of the MOF. Proton conductivity of 1 up to the penta-hydrate state is low. Thereafter, addition of water molecules enhances its conductivity significantly suggesting that the water molecules in the channel play important role in the proton conduction probably due to the formation of hydrogen bond networks. The results suggest that small amount of protons are coordinated by water and the emerged oxonium ion acts as proton carrier. According to the literature, possibly Grötthuss type of conduction takes place here with the participation of water molecules and the aligned imidazolium groups. However, this compound does not give high proton conductivity compared to the Zn(II) coordination polymer. This is most likely due to inefficient Grötthuss type of conduction as the nitrate anion is coordinated to the metal center. This assumes importance as in the previous case, the nitrate anion was free. As we are synthesizing other PCPs for high proton conductivity, this study gives us an important starting point.

elements.content: Proton conductivity dependency of 1 on amount of adsorbed water. Open and closed circles represent the adsorption and desorption, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 7  Proton conductivity dependency of 1 on amount of adsorbed water. Open and closed circles represent the adsorption and desorption, respectively.

elements.content: In summary, we report an uncommon coordination polymer built with Cd(II) and a bent ligand containing aromatic carboxylate as terminals and an imidazolium group in the middle. The ligand topology and the coordination tendency of the d10 metal ion leads to a highly catenated structure. The overall structure contains 1D channels along the crystallographic a-axis where the imidazolium groups are partially aligned. The channels also contain water and DMF molecules that can be removed upon heating without destroying the overall structure. This compound exhibits a considerable proton conduction on humidification at ambient temperature. The conductivity has clear dependence on the amount of water adsorbed although it does not change to any significant extent with increasing temperature. However, the conductivity values are not as high as the MOF built with Zn(II) ion. The imidazolium groups although aligned in the channels, they are not closely packed and this may be one of the main reasons for low conductivity compared to the Zn(II) compound. Besides, the nitrate anion is metal bound in the present complex while it was free in the previous PCP. This study, therefore, offers us clues to synthesize more PCPs for better proton conductivity. We are presently working along these lines.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we report an uncommon coordination polymer built with Cd(II) and a bent ligand containing aromatic carboxylate as terminals and an imidazolium group in the middle. The ligand topology and the coordination tendency of the d10 metal ion leads to a highly catenated structure. The overall structure contains 1D channels along the crystallographic a-axis where the imidazolium groups are partially aligned. The channels also contain water and DMF molecules that can be removed upon heating without destroying the overall structure. This compound exhibits a considerable proton conduction on humidification at ambient temperature. The conductivity has clear dependence on the amount of water adsorbed although it does not change to any significant extent with increasing temperature. However, the conductivity values are not as high as the MOF built with Zn(II) ion. The imidazolium groups although aligned in the channels, they are not closely packed and this may be one of the main reasons for low conductivity compared to the Zn(II) compound. Besides, the nitrate anion is metal bound in the present complex while it was free in the previous PCP. This study, therefore, offers us clues to synthesize more PCPs for better proton conductivity. We are presently working along these lines.

The ligand 1, 3-bis-(4-carboxyphenyl)imidazolium chloride (H2L+Cl–) was synthesized in several steps as reported earlier.

Synthesis of [Cd<sub>2</sub>(L)<sub>3</sub>(DMF)(NO<sub>3</sub>)]·(DMF)<sub>3</sub>·(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>8</sub>(<bold>1</bold>)

This compound was synthesized by mixing H2L+Cl– (1 mmol) and Cd(NO3)2·6H2O (4 mmol) in DMF (3 mL) in a Teflon-lined autoclave. It was heated under autogenous pressure to 85 °C for 48 h. Cooling to room temperature at the rate of 10 °C h–1 afforded the desired product as colorless needle-shaped crystals in ca. 66% yield. It was collected by filtration, washed thoroughly with DMF followed by ethanol and dried in air. Anal. Calcd for C63H77N11O27Cd2: C, 45.99; H, 4.72; N, 9.37%. Found: C, 46.13; H, 4.93; N, 9.24%.

Synthesis

Synthesis of [Cd2(L)3(DMF)(NO3)]⋅(DMF)3⋅(H2O)8(1)

This compound was synthesized by mixing H2L+Cl- (1 mmol) and Cd(NO3)2⋅6H2O (4 mmol) in DMF (3 mL) in a Teflon-lined autoclave. It was heated under autogenous pressure to 85 °C for 48 h. Cooling to room temperature at the rate of 10 °C h-1 afforded the desired product as colorless needle-shaped crystals in ca. 66% yield. cln_elements.content:
A novel entangled architecture formed on solvothermal reaction of a imidazolium based bent ligand with Cd(NO3)2, showing 1D channels decorated with imidazolium groups, is reported. The polymer, {[Cd2(L)3(DMF)(NO3)](DMF)3(H2O)8} n (1) (where H2L = 1,3-bis(4-carboxyphenyl)imidazolium, DMF = dimethylformamide), shows an interesting 6,3-connected polycatenated structure with channels along the crystallographic b-axis occupied with large number of DMF and water molecules. On removal of these solvent molecules the compound maintains its overall structure. Proton conductivity investigation affords a proton conductivity of 1.3 × 10–5 Scm–1 at 25 °C and 98% RH when water molecules are introduced into the empty channels.

AC Impedance Measurement

Impedance measurements were carried out using a pellet of 2.5 mm thickness as described earlier.

Results and Discussion

Compound 1 once isolated, is found to be air-stable and insoluble in common organic solvents and water. Thermal analysis of 1 shows ( Figure S1) loss of weight of ∼26.5% in the range, 40–200 °C corresponding to the removal of free as well as coordinated solvent molecules. Decomposition of the compound is achieved beyond 350 °C. A broad peak in the IR spectrum ( Figure S2) at 3224 cm–1 appears due to water molecules and strong peaks are observed at 1607 and 2921 cm–1 attributable to the CO and C–H stretching of coordinated DMF molecules respectively. The asymmetric stretching vibration of the chelating nitrate is observed at 1258 cm–1. Single crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c. The asymmetric unit contains two crystallographically independent Cd(II) ions; octa-coordinated Cd1 and hexacoordinated Cd2 (Figure ).

The overall 3D structure of 1 also features channels along the b-axis (Figure b and c). The channels are not empty but contain water and dimethylformamide molecules as guests. Dimension of each channel is 11.09 × 10.63 Å2 based on the distances of the opposite atoms (Figure b). Some of the methylene groups of the imidazolium moieties are directed toward the center of the channel (Figure c). The variable temperature powder X-ray diffraction studies confirms the stability of the framework ( Figure S4).

Proton conductivity was evaluated by AC impedance spectroscopy using a compacted pellet of the powdered sample with two gold electrodes attached to the surface. Detailed experimental procedures are available elsewhere. Proton conductivity of 1 gradually increases with increase of humidity and it reaches the value of 1.3 × 10–5 S cm–1 at 25 °C under 98% relative humidity (RH) (Figure ). The conductivity increases by about 4 orders of magnitude, from 9.8 × 10–10 at 40% RH to 1.3 × 10–5 S cm–1 at 98% RH.
cln_elements.clean_text:
A novel entangled architecture formed on solvothermal reaction of a imidazolium based bent ligand with Cd(NO3)2, showing 1D channels decorated with imidazolium groups, is reported. The polymer, {[Cd2(L)3(DMF)(NO3)](DMF)3(H2O)8} n  (1) (where H2L = 1,3-bis(4-carboxyphenyl)imidazolium, DMF = dimethylformamide), shows an interesting 6,3-connected polycatenated structure with channels along the crystallographic b-axis occupied with large number of DMF and water molecules. On removal of these solvent molecules the compound maintains its overall structure. Proton conductivity investigation affords a proton conductivity of 1.3 × 10-5 Scm-1 at 25 °C and 98% RH when water molecules are introduced into the empty channels.

AC Impedance Measurement

Impedance measurements were carried out using a pellet of 2.5 mm thickness as described earlier. 

Results and Discussion

Compound 1 once isolated, is found to be air-stable and insoluble in common organic solvents and water. Thermal analysis of 1 shows ( Figure S1) loss of weight of ~26.5% in the range, 40-200 °C corresponding to the removal of free as well as coordinated solvent molecules. Decomposition of the compound is achieved beyond 350 °C. A broad peak in the IR spectrum ( Figure S2) at 3224 cm-1 appears due to water molecules and strong peaks are observed at 1607 and 2921 cm-1 attributable to the CO and C-H stretching of coordinated DMF molecules respectively. The asymmetric stretching vibration of the chelating nitrate is observed at 1258 cm-1. Single crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c. The asymmetric unit contains two crystallographically independent Cd(II) ions; octa-coordinated Cd1 and hexacoordinated Cd2 (Figure ).

The overall 3D structure of 1 also features channels along the b-axis (Figure b and c). The channels are not empty but contain water and dimethylformamide molecules as guests. Dimension of each channel is 11.09 × 10.63 Å2 based on the distances of the opposite atoms (Figure b). Some of the methylene groups of the imidazolium moieties are directed toward the center of the channel (Figure c). The variable temperature powder X-ray diffraction studies confirms the stability of the framework ( Figure S4).

Proton conductivity was evaluated by AC impedance spectroscopy using a compacted pellet of the powdered sample with two gold electrodes attached to the surface. Detailed experimental procedures are available elsewhere. Proton conductivity of 1 gradually increases with increase of humidity and it reaches the value of 1.3 × 10-5 S cm-1 at 25 °C under 98% relative humidity (RH) (Figure ). The conductivity increases by about 4 orders of magnitude, from 9.8 × 10-10 at 40% RH to 1.3 × 10-5 S cm-1 at 98% RH.

pore diameter.condition: based on the distances of the opposite atoms

metadata.title:
3D Coordination Polymer of Cd(II) with an Imidazolium-Based
Linker Showing Parallel Polycatenation Forming Channels with Aligned
Imidazolium Groups
